questions.text: What word does Osama Bin Laden mispronounce in the beginning of the episode?
questions.explanation:
Ramadan.

	In the beginning of the episode, Osama Bin Laden is in a cave somewhere in Afghanistan, and he's trying to film a tape for the U.S., but himself and everyone around him can't stop laughing.  Eventually, Stewie appears and fights them all.  The credits then roll much like they did in the movie "Naked Gun" where a camera was placed on a police car's dashboard as it drove through a whole bunch of silly places.

questions.text: What was Meg's first grade play?
questions.explanation:
Robin Hood.

	Lois dragged Peter to the play and he ended up making stupid comments while the students were performing.  This play is brought up because Peter wants to stay home and watch the Emmy Awards rather than be at Meg's play.

questions.text: What coloured carpet does Peter try to put in his bedroom?
questions.explanation:
Red.

	Peter does this because the Emmys are going to be on TV.  Unluckily, he happens to wake up Lois early in the morning because he begins stapling the carpet to the floor next to the bed.  She ends up forcing him to stop carpeting and he goes to Meg's play.

questions.text: According to the news, how did Bob Hope die a second time?
options: A radio fell on his head
questions.explanation:
In a motorcycle crash.

	After the play, Peter watches the news to view highlights of the Emmy Awards and Tom Tucker says that Bob Hope came back to life for the show.  After, he ended up trying to jump trash cans on his motorcycle and it burst into flames.

questions.text: According to the FCC, how many calls does it take for twenty billion people to notice something bad on TV?
questions.explanation:
Twenty.

	The FCC decides to take action when David Hyde Pierce accidentally has a 'wardrobe malfunction' on the Emmy Awards, and after they get twenty calls from viewers, they assume that twenty billion people were outraged.  After this incident, the FCC begins censoring totally pointless things on television.

questions.text: What company did Peter once work for?
questions.explanation:
ACME.

	During a flashback, Peter is assisting a customer who complains about a slingshot that he bought.  The customer turns out to be Wile E. Coyote, and the slingshot had thrown him into a mountain.  Wile E. ends up taking store credit after Peter suggests it to him.

questions.text: What is the name of Quagmire's show on PTV?
questions.explanation:
Midnight Q.

	After the FCC ruins television for Peter, he decides to create his own TV station so that he can air nudity, flatulence, violence, and crude language.  On the station, he decides to air original programming including a TV show starring Brian and Stewie called "Cheeky Bastard", and Quagmire's talk show, "Midnight Q".

questions.text: Who doesn't sing during the FCC song in this episode?
questions.explanation:
Lois.

	When Lois is disgusted with Peter's programming on PTV, she thinks that Peter's setting a bad influence for children.  Peter, Stewie, and Brian tell her about the situation through song and a montage of previous crude jokes on the show since it began.  Eventually, Lois does think that the FCC has gone too far.

questions.text: According to the FCC, Ozzy Osbourne changed after he stopped eating bats during concerts.  What does he eat as a replacement?
questions.explanation:
Sandwiches.

	After the FCC realizes that Peter has been airing inappropriate programs, they shut down his TV station and they decide to censor everyone in Quahog by following people around and using practical ideas to stop people from swearing, passing gas, etc.  They say that their techniques have changed Ozzy from a crazy, abusive man to a gentler Ozzy Osbourne.  Instead of eating the head off a bat, he now tells the audience he'll eat a full sandwich before starting his act.

questions.text: After Lois realizes that the FCC has gone too far, where does the family travel to take action?
questions.explanation:
Washington D. C.

	When the family gets to Washington D. C., Peter tells the government that they can't possibly censor everything when inappropriate stuff is all around them.  He begins pointing out how various landmarks in Washington D. C. look like inappropriate things and they agree that the FCC was wrong.  In the end, everyone gets their normal programs back, free of censoring.
